title: Need help identifying a book typeface (samples).
content:
Hi everybody,  
Here’s a font I can’t quite identify. It reminds me of Caslon but it seems more  
rounded, compact, and ‘heavy’. I’ve tried using the Serif Font Identification Guide but did not find a match.  
The book is a 1997 reprint of a 1971 edition of Michel Foucault’s ‘Madness and Civilization’.  
Hope someone can at least give me a pointer.  
Thanks in advance.

| Attachment | Size |
| --- | --- |
| [1.JPG](http://web.archive.org/web/20070309184052/http:/typophile.com/files/1.JPG) | 71.27 KB |
| [2.JPG](http://web.archive.org/web/20070309184052/http:/typophile.com/files/2.JPG) | 85.59 KB |
| [caps.JPG](http://web.archive.org/web/20070309184052/http:/typophile.com/files/caps.JPG) | 958.48 KB |
| [3.JPG](http://web.archive.org/web/20070309184052/http:/typophile.com/files/3.JPG) | 96.79 KB |
| [italics.JPG](http://web.archive.org/web/20070309184052/http:/typophile.com/files/italics.JPG) | 66.91 KB |
author: byronic

comments.content:
I’m guessing [Janson](http://web.archive.org/web/20070309184052/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/urw/janson/).

EDIT: Not sure what the Caps.jpg is though. It’s Caslon-esque.

That was my thought too. It’s not the Monotype version, but i also doubt it’s the URW. I’m guessing maybe the Berthold Janson Antiqua, but I haven’t looked at all your samples yet.

- Mike Yanega

Thanks, I was thinking of Janson too.  
But I haven’t been able to match the peculiar italic ‘f’, for example. Or the capital G.
I agree, I think the caps are Caslon. The text itself strikes me as some kind of mongrel between (especially) janson and caslon - but I love the font.

Yes, the italic f is giving me problems too. I was hoping some of the other Kis fonts might show the difference, but so far I haven’t seen it. The chin on the G and the oddly splayed M and the drooping ‘g’ ear are Kis/Janson hallmarks, so I still don’t think this is Caslon.

You say that the book is a reprint of a 1971 book. I wonder if they used the old plates, and that this is a metal version of the type.

- Mike Yanega

Your caps sample shows a different typeface than the text samples. I agree that the A, in particular, looks like Caslon. Now I wonder if the italic is from a third face?

- Mike Yanega
The capital M isn’t tilted either, like in Janson.

I have found some old versions of Caslon that have a similar italic f by looking in the McGrew book of metal typefaces. I believe the italic is some sort of Caslon which I have not been able to match across the board.The italic A in your sample also has the Caslon ‘notch’ at the apex, I think.

- Mike Yanega

Yes, it’s quite possible that it’s a metal face. It certainly looks ‘uneven’ like a metal impression.  
EDIT: By the way I’ve discovered the italic ‘f’ is more or less identical to Sabon. More mystery.
